review_text:
I just love me a battle royale that's somewhat grounded in reality. 
I love projectile-based combat. 
I love at least an attempt made, to keep real-world guns true to their real forms.
Leaning, ADS, prone, shoulder-fire AND hip fire options are great to have and play with.
Big maps. Lots of verticality. 

And its now free. 
It's just a good game imo. Very difficult. But reallllyy fun.

First review on Steam.

Pros:
- Stunning scenes with adaptive lighting, bloom, focus blur, and filters. Combine it with camera work and it's a marvel of game visuals.
- Lots of customization options.
- Calming BGM + satisfying ASMR SFX. Even as you hover over colors to pick, there are singular xylophone sounds playing with each option.
- Highly adaptive procedural adaptations as well as decorative nuances. Bird nests popping up in roof creases and sheeps floating with umbrellas being my cherries-on-top.
- No visible limiting grid, or as they'd say, 'gridless.'
- Very low price compared to what it offers.
- Demo save transfers well into the full game.

Some introductory tutorials in sandbox games can be invasive and interrupting a smooth gameplay, especially if you skip it or will miss something major if you do. This game isn't about that.

You're welcome to explore on your own what this droplet button does, what dragging this wall sideways will do, what will happen if you choose to put three windows together, etc. With the vast customization and options, I find that in my first 3 hours of playing, I keep learning new things non-stop.

You're not spoon-fed with rules, told to run tasks, follow a story, or even taught how to do things - instead, you adapt on your own, just like how the game adapts to what little changes you do. You make the glade feel like home, and the game gladly returns the favor, creating a flourishing mutualistic ecosystem and the humbling sandbox experience that the game is.

Bugs found:
- Certain bugs for item positioning/adaptation. Ex: ivy remains floating in the air from removed/shrunk buildings.
- Camera bugs. Ex: camera got stuck in one zoomed angle, can still move but always returns to the stuck angle. Restarting the game resets it and no progress were lost.

Suggestions for developers to add:

- Options to group objects together
- Controls to lock & unlock objects from moving or changing
- Controls to copy, cut, and paste objects/group of objects
- Options to pick and drop color, also to color multiple objects at once
- Options to enable interactive humans/humanoid characters to inhabit or explore glades the way wild animals do
- Additional water/terrain option: automatic square or circular shape in addition to the manual drawing option
- Additional delete option: wipe the entire scene out of trees, buildings, etc with just one click
- Options to manually add furniture/items for decor aside from automatic procedural adaptations
- Options to generate bridges with different styles (as opposed to people manually making it with building tricks)
- Options to generate stairs with different styles (as opposed to people also manually making it with building tricks)
- Options to generate moving water like rivers or waterfalls.
- Options to generate more terrain items like stones, logs, stumps, as well as more variation of flowers and plants.
- Additional options to change the weather, i.e cloudy, raining, etc
- And ofc more choice for scenes & building styles, perhaps some that captures dark gothic aesthetic or eastern/oriental style designs if that already hasn't been in development (highly suspect it has)

Aside from how well-developed this game already is, I really appreciate how well-loved it is too, both by the players and developers. This seems like a game my past younger self, my current self, and my future elderly self, all would love to play regardless of time and relevance.

I'm 7 years old, running through fields and exploring castle ruins. The charm of the historic cobblestone streets, flower pots in the windows, perfect little gardens in it all. The meadows where the cows pass through, the bells around their necks ring.

I have been waiting for this game to come out for quite some time, the simple relaxing nature of the tiny glade drew me in for a chill gaming experience, I was not disappointed. Its a charming and creative experience for when you don't want a shooter or strategy game. Its a good way to unwind after a long day, something to do when you want to express your creativity, or you just want to escape to your little slice of peaceful bliss. Don't expect to "win" or "lose" in this game, there is no victory conditions, just build a castle or what once was a castle, build a farm, a town, or a village, its up to your interpretation. I do wish the glade wasn't so... tiny, and I wish you could control, move, and spawn more animals, but its a small nitpick.

Its a game that can take you somewhere new, or back in time, or so it feels. I may not be 7 anymore, I'm an adult with responsibilities, people that depend on me, a day that is filled with more busy time than free time, but for now, I'm just going to forget about all of that, and go back to when life was simpler, at least for 5 more minutes.

An amazing and chill little game. If this receives more tools and/or a workshop it'll be insanely more replayable than it already is. Don't go into it expecting much besides a chill little city/village builder. Plop down building on the terrain like paint on a canvas and let your creativity flow.

I was wary of playing Cyberpunk's base game after the reviews when it just came out, but grew increasingly curious about the game after watching the anime. After finally folding and purchasing the base game at a discount, I quickly grew to love the combat system, methods of gaining power, and especially the story the game told. The most important part of any game to me is the story, followed by the combat mechanics, then the graphics. Cyberpunk smashed all my expectations so much so that I purchased Phantom Liberty at full price when I was halfway through the game, solely because I knew I wanted more content before the end of the game. I'm very glad I did. The DLC has been wonderful, and without spoiling it, I would rate it 2 tiers above the base game (7/10 - base, 9/10 DlC, for an average of 8/10). Note that 5/10 simply means "average" and reasonable for the experience/price. I fully recommend the DLC if you enjoyed the base game.

"Balls to the Wall" -- completely bugged.

1. For some reason, when the chase starts and you get hit by a car and continue driving, we did not continue. Our car got pushed to the gate and didn't move. I had to restart.
2. Then when you start fighting scavs, it's needlessly hard. It's my 2nd playthrough, on hard difficulty. On hard, I killed Adam Smasher on 2nd try at just lvl 35 with sucky cyberware, and I'd say Adam Smasher is one of the hardest bosses in the game. This thing took me 5 tries. My advice -- when you get out of car, you get blades. Forget the blades, get back to pistol, find cover and be very careful as they'll shred you very quickly. Be careful with skulls and netrunners. First time I got killed by a runner.
3. After finally doing this, I go to the "wounded scav" and... nothing happens. It's bugged again. Trust me, I tried everything and I don't think I did anything unusual to cause it. 

At this point I just lost it. Come on, The DLC had been out for a year now, and the base game is 4 years old at this point. I understand that making games of this scale is hard. Even after 4 years, in the base game content, I still encounter some small bugs but I'm like "okay, no biggie". But this is just not acceptable quality.

ending made me cry.

An excellent story based DLC spy story addition to CP2077. The start and the finish of the story are cinema worthy in their scope and dramatic work. It does rather lag in the middle whilst you go and do other jobs to fill in time until the main plot resumes. However, this is more an issue with the genre rather than this DLC in particular.
The voice acting is very good, the new weapons, items and locations are good, though most of the good work was done by the 2.0 patch to the base game.
Overall, a very good addition to CP2077, and here's hoping for more, or for similar quality in the next game.

It's shocking to believe that this expansion is something that came out as good as it did despite the base game. The main story to this DLC is a lot more linear than the base game's, and it is all the better for it. There is focus, there is amazing pacing. The characters introduced are likable, which is far more than I can say for quite a few of the characters in the base game. There were decisions given to the player that were hard to make. The game, through these decisions, makes you ask what it is that is important to you. Is it ideals, loyalty, freedom, what aspect of life do you value? And who will suffer for your decision to follow these ideals? It is an excellent narrative with an amazing musical score, great story and wonderful writing, and I cannot recommend it enough. Leagues better than the base game.

TL;DR stop looking at reviews and play the game! Cyberpunk 2077: Phantom Library is one of the best expansions to one of the best games ever made. I have a gtx 1070 and it ran fine at 1080p most of the time I played at high or ultra but I had to turn it down to medium sometimes.
Best DLC ever

In my honest opinion Phantom Liberty has some of the best story telling of any game I've played in 40+ years. It's the closest thing I've encountered to really giving you that Blade Runner experience where every choice you make really has consequences not just for your character, but for the entire world of Cyberpunk, and just like the world of Blade Runner there really are no happy ending. I haven't experienced that kind of make you sit back and reflect on the things that you did to get you where you had to go since Geralt found Ciri in The Witcher 3. I look forward to enjoying it again. Phantom Liberty is immersive story telling at its best.
One of the Best Story DLCs I've seen in recent years. Loved the story and sat a solid 10 minutes at the end pondering what decisions to make.

An extremely well polished thriller. I was absolutely hooked! As I mentioned in my review of the base game, the decisions you make in the base game and DLC, and their consequences stay in your mind even long after you're done playing the game.

The game is in a very good state now than it was at launch, and I highly recommend playing it now if you didn't back when it launched.

The keyboard & mouse controls are awfully clunky. The camera jerks around because of some kind of snapping clearly designed for controller use. Moving the mouse does not continuously turn the plane, so you have to swipe over and over to turn the plan around.

Aside from controls, the movement in general feels very "gamey" and unrealistic. The combat is not very challenging even on hard mode - enemies can be killed with a single missile but your own plane only takes 50% damage from an enemy missile. 

The script is badly translated and the voice acting is cringe, but kind of funny at times.

Ace Combat 7 is a vary good game and highly detailed but its also not the most realistic game but its fun.

I'll break this down simply.
The most realistic parts of this game and series as a whole:
- The look of the aircraft, ordinance, and effects.
- Some of the atmospheric effects: weather, vector trails, vapour, albeit no contrails above FL300ish as of yet.
- The diversity in aircraft types.
- The air battle management dialogue and presentation, which is fairly well depicted for a video game. It's clear that they consulted with real Tactical Air Traffic controllers on some level.
- The depiction of Tactical Data Link in a practical sense, especially with regard to ID classification.
- Playtime WRT length of missions.
- Plot points such as electronic warfare, drones, AI.
The least realistic parts:
- Let's be honest, ammunition load-out storage. Ridiculous. But the missions would be 5 minutes long, force you to land and take off repeatedly, or only have a couple land targets and a single enemy fighter group otherwise.
- Mechanics of fighter jet flight. Totally ridiculous. But fun and arcade-esque.
- Mechanics of air weapon flight. Ridiculous to keep up with the aircraft they are targeting. Fair enough.
- Fidelity of radar, comms, and link coverage. Not realistic for things to just work perfectly everywhere always. Just a game though.
- Plot points such as gigantic aircraft carriers, rail guns, and space elevators. Too expensive in the real world to ever make sense. Alluring as a fantasy depiction for sure.
- Pilot response to the ridiculous acceleration/deceleration and +/-G forces. That is not at all depicted in the series during gameplay. However it is mentioned in cutscenes.
- Supersonic depiction, something that I have only seen accurately depicted in flight simulator.
- It would be cool to have an depiction of Mach, IAS, and TAS if not for pure effect.
- It would be cool to have the cockpit depict information completely much like the VR presentation.

If I missed anything... well you'll see. I highly recommend any game in this series. This is the best seller for a reason but the story is a little more compelling in AC4 and its subsequent releases. Hopefully one day we will get remakes and remasters because these games have a lot of replayability and the older titles are kind of forgotten given their generation. The developers don't have to improve too much to keep fans happy, aside from a better multiplayer experience and some minor touch-ups, such as inaccurate sound effects and a storyline that isn't really very sad.

LET ME EXPLAIN. Overall, I love this game. I really do. If I ignore Mario Games, Grounded has become my favorite video game of all time. I got into the game on version 1.3. Played the PC Pass Version with my friend, nearly finished the game. We quit right before 1.4 because we got busy.
Loved the game so much that I decided to buy it on Steam. I wanted to 100% it on Whoa! difficulty. Before I started this playthrough, I did see online about how bad 1.4 was balanced. I even saw how some YouTubers who focused on Grounded quit the game.
Now I see what they were talking about. When I started my 100% playthrough, it was right before 1.4.4. The game still has a bad balancing issue. NG+ is still just broken and unbalanced. to the point where it isn't enjoyable. Two examples: an infused bug can have the sour or fresh spell. They are just insane and barely possible to stop. I was pre-NG+ maxed out on equipment and stats. Even Infused Lawn Mites are a struggle. Also, it is now a grind to get the gear maxed out. The amount of fusion crystals it takes to upgrade a weapon from 9-15 is 105, and the time to get that is just nuts.

If you ignore NG+, the game really is amazing. I really do love this game, but NG+ balancing is just terrible. People can comment that it is a skill issue, but 1.4.4 didn't help much.

Pros:
Runs beyond perfectly on modern computers
Entertaining gameplay loop
Intuitive controls
Interesting Lore
Always something to do while you wait
Fun with or without friends
Dedicated devs
Few to no detrimental bugs
Challenges your brain
Near endless content

Cons:
Challenges your brain (Derogatory)
Not suited for short play sessions
Progress is much slower without doing hard math
Most systems won't be able to run highest graphics
Semi-frequent multiplayer desync

Personal Gripes/Feature suggestions:
Give us more Pipe junctions (t-junction, 3-way elbow, etc)
Gas mask needs buffs
AWESOME shop rails should snap to walkways, but don't
